Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: An Integrated Approach to Convex Optimization Algorithms
Award.AbstractNarration:
Image reconstruction and feature extraction have been important aspects in various applications such as medical resonance imaging (MRI) and synthetic aperture radar (SAR). However, these procedures involve challenges. Different applications may vary in data acquisition (sampling) domains, levels of detail required, and processing domains for the features of interest. The data acquisition is usually under-prescribed and noisy. The sampling domains and/or processing domains may not be well suited for the underlying question. All of these make the problems ill-posed, and various regularization techniques are necessary to study the problems by formulating them as convex optimization models. This project will develop an integrated framework of investigating such convex optimization models. The project will provide graduate students with opportunities for training through research involvement and will prepare them for careers in science and engineering.

The PIs aim to propose a systematic way of evaluating various regularization techniques in such models, conduct a rigorous numerical analysis of the models, and develop efficient numerical algorithms of solving the models. Specifically, the PIs will address the following technical questions: (1) What constraints must be placed on the collected data in order to construct a numerically robust approximation to the underlying function? (2) How quickly and in what sense does the approximation converge? (3) Are the corresponding numerical algorithms developed for the fidelity and regularization terms viable? (4) How well are perturbations from the original data tolerated? The project aims to provide answers to all of these questions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main objective of this proposal was to develop techniques for solving ill posed inverse problems for image reconstruction and feature extraction from under-sampled and noisy data. In particular, the focus was on non-traditional Fourier measurements that was not amenable to conventional numerical transformations. Our investigations focused on three main areas: (i) How to best impose prior information about sparsity to regularize convex optimization methods; (ii) how to rigorously analyze convergence properties of function/image reconstruction from non-standard data; and (iii) how to apply newly developed algorithms to real problems, such as those that occur in magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) or synthetic aperture radar (SAR).

The first significant accomplishment from this project was to introduce a systematic way of studying the non-uniform Fourier reconstruction problem through using tools in frame theory. A stable and accurate method to approximate the inverse frame operator was developed and had been applied to MRI and SAR imaging.

Moreover, a novel two-stage framework was designed to reconstruct medical images from Fourier measurements. A processing domain was introduced to bridge the sampling space and regularization space to accurately represent the underlying functions/images. This technique yielded superior performance compared to several state of the art one-stage methods.

The third signification accomplishment was the development of the variance based joint sparsity method for multi-measurement vectors (MMV). We introduced a variance-based technique to boost the performance of each individual reconstruction through exploiting the special structures of the multi-measurement vectors. The method could also be automated, so that no additional tuning of parameters was needed. The effectiveness of this method was successfully implemented in parallel MRI and SAR data.

PI Song mentored undergraduate students each summer and recruited one student to the Clarkson PhD program to continue research based on this project. Song also incorporated findings from this research project into a new course on convex optimization. Song organized five mini-symposia in various conferences, including the SIAM Annual Meeting, SIAM CSE, and SIAM Imaging. Project results had been presented at international conferences, departmental colloquia, and seminars, in discussion of them with mathematicians and domain scientists. Finally, in addition to using these methods in applications such as MRI, SAR, and SAS, Song is planning to extend them to other domains including ultrasound applications.
